@graph.name: Value Proposition Development Framework Ontology
@graph.description: A comprehensive ontology for systematically developing, validating, and articulating value propositions through structured problem definition, market analysis, solution design, and value creation processes. Applicable across B2B and B2C contexts, any market, and any product/service offering.

schemaOrgAlignment.extensionRationale: Schema.org provides foundational types for business concepts, actions, and measurements. Extensions are needed for specific value proposition methodology constructs.

@graph.name: Problem
@graph.description: A challenge, difficulty, or unmet need experienced by a target customer that creates negative consequences and represents an opportunity for value creation. Problems are analyzed across functional, economic, emotional, and social dimensions.

properties.description: Clear, concise statement of the core problem in the format: [TARGET CUSTOMER] struggles with [SPECIFIC CHALLENGE] when trying to [DESIRED OUTCOME], which results in [NEGATIVE CONSEQUENCES].
Severity level of the problem impact
How often the problem is experienced
Whether the problem is growing or diminishing over time
Estimated market size for the problem (TAM, SAM, SOM)

relationships.name: affects
relationships.description: The customer segments that experience this problem

relationships.name: hasPainPoint
relationships.description: Specific pain points that constitute the problem

relationships.name: hasConsequence
relationships.description: Negative outcomes resulting from the problem

relationships.name: triggeredBy
relationships.description: Events or circumstances that trigger the problem

relationships.name: addressedBy
relationships.description: Existing solutions customers currently use

relationships.name: validatedBy
relationships.description: Evidence supporting the existence and significance of the problem

businessRules: Every Problem MUST have at least one PainPoint
Every Problem MUST have at least one Consequence
Every Problem MUST be validated by at least one ValidationEvidence
Problem severity and frequency should be validated with quantitative data when possible
Problems should be analyzed in the context of the customer journey
@graph.aiAgentGuidance: When reasoning about Problems, analyze root causes vs symptoms, quantify impact when possible, and map the complete context including triggers, current solutions, and stakeholder perspectives.

@graph.name: Pain Point
@graph.description: A specific source of difficulty, frustration, or inefficiency experienced by customers. Pain points are categorized into functional, economic, emotional, and social dimensions.

properties.description: Detailed description of the pain point
The dimension of pain being experienced
How this pain point impacts the customer
Quantified measure of impact (cost, time, etc.)

@graph.name: Consequence
@graph.description: A negative outcome or impact that results from an unsolved problem. Consequences can be direct costs, opportunity costs, or risks.

properties.description: Time lost or wasted due to the consequence

@graph.name: Target Customer
@graph.description: The specific customer segment that experiences the problem and is the focus of the value proposition. Can be an organization (B2B) or person (B2C).

properties.description: Detailed description of customer segment characteristics
Assessed willingness to pay for solution

relationships.name: hasStakeholder
relationships.description: The various stakeholder roles within or related to the customer

relationships.name: participatesIn
relationships.description: The customer journeys this target customer experiences

@graph.name: Stakeholder
@graph.description: A person or group with a specific role in relation to the problem and solution. Includes users, decision makers, influencers, and beneficiaries.

properties.description: Description of the stakeholder and their interests
Level of influence on purchase decision

@graph.name: Current Solution
@graph.description: An existing approach, product, service, or workaround that customers currently use to address the problem. Understanding current solutions reveals gaps and opportunities for differentiation.

properties.description: Description of how customers currently solve the problem

relationships.name: hasGap
relationships.description: Limitations or shortcomings of this solution

relationships.name: hasSwitchingCost
relationships.description: Costs associated with switching from this solution

@graph.name: Solution Gap
@graph.description: A limitation, shortcoming, or unmet need in current solutions. Solution gaps represent opportunities for differentiation.

properties.description: Description of what is missing or inadequate
How severe the gap is for customers

@graph.name: Validation Evidence
@graph.description: Data, research, or information that validates the existence and significance of a problem. Evidence sources include customer interviews, market research, competitive analysis, and industry reports.

properties.description: Description of what the evidence shows

@graph.name: Market Context
@graph.description: The broader market environment including segments, competitive landscape, industry trends, and regulatory factors that influence the problem and opportunity.

relationships.name: hasSegment
relationships.description: Market segments within this context

relationships.name: hasCompetitor
relationships.description: Competitive alternatives in the market

relationships.name: influencedBy
relationships.description: Market trends affecting the context

relationships.name: constrainedBy
relationships.description: Regulatory constraints in the market

@graph.name: Solution
@graph.description: The proposed product, service, or approach that addresses the identified problem and delivers value to target customers.

properties.description: The primary capabilities of the solution
How the solution reaches the customer

relationships.name: addresses
relationships.description: The problems this solution addresses

relationships.name: hasFeature
relationships.description: Specific features that comprise the solution

relationships.name: delivers
relationships.description: Benefits delivered by the solution

relationships.name: differentiatedBy
relationships.description: How this solution is differentiated from alternatives

relationships.name: implementedVia
relationships.description: How the solution is implemented

businessRules: Every Solution MUST address at least one Problem
Every Solution MUST have at least one Differentiator
Every Solution MUST deliver at least one measurable Benefit
Solution design should align with customer workflows and mental models

@graph.name: Feature
@graph.description: A specific capability, function, or characteristic of the solution that contributes to value delivery.

properties.description: Detailed description of what the feature does

relationships.name: enables
relationships.description: Benefits enabled by this feature

relationships.name: addresses
relationships.description: Pain points addressed by this feature

@graph.name: Benefit
@graph.description: A positive outcome or value delivered to customers by the solution. Benefits can be quantifiable (cost savings, revenue growth) or qualitative (improved experience, strategic advantage).

properties.description: Whether the benefit is quantifiable or qualitative
Quantified measure of the benefit (for quantifiable benefits)

relationships.name: mitigates
relationships.description: Pain points mitigated by this benefit

relationships.name: evidencedBy
relationships.description: Evidence supporting the benefit claim

@graph.name: Differentiator
@graph.description: A unique aspect of the solution that distinguishes it from competitive alternatives. Differentiators can be based on approach, technology, capability, or business model.

properties.description: Description of how this differentiates the solution
The specific advantage this provides over alternatives
How defensible this differentiator is (difficult to copy)
How important this differentiator is to target customers

@graph.name: Competitive Alternative
@graph.description: An existing product, service, or approach that competes with the proposed solution. Understanding competitive alternatives enables effective differentiation.

@graph.name: Value Proposition
@graph.description: The complete articulation of how the solution creates value for target customers by addressing their problems better than alternatives. Includes the value proposition statement, supporting messages, and evidence.

properties.description: The primary value proposition statement following the format: For [TARGET CUSTOMER] who [NEEDS STATEMENT], our [PRODUCT/SERVICE] provides [KEY BENEFITS] unlike [COMPETITIVE ALTERNATIVES] because [UNIQUE DIFFERENTIATORS].
Alternative format: Our [PRODUCT/SERVICE] enables [TARGET CUSTOMER] to [KEY BENEFIT] through [UNIQUE APPROACH].
Summary of what makes this solution unique

relationships.name: targets
relationships.description: The customer segments targeted by this value proposition

relationships.name: addresses
relationships.description: The problems addressed by this value proposition

relationships.name: offeredThrough
relationships.description: The solution offering the value

relationships.name: communicatedVia
relationships.description: The messaging framework for communicating the value proposition

relationships.name: supportedBy
relationships.description: Evidence supporting the value proposition claims

relationships.name: differentiatesFrom
relationships.description: Competitive alternatives this value proposition differentiates from

businessRules: Every ValueProposition MUST have a primaryStatement
Every ValueProposition MUST target at least one TargetCustomer
Every ValueProposition MUST address at least one Problem
Every ValueProposition MUST be supported by ValueEvidence
The value proposition should be validated with target customers before finalization

@graph.name: Messaging Framework
@graph.description: A structured approach to communicating the value proposition across different channels and to different stakeholders. Includes primary message, supporting messages, proof points, and emotional hooks.

properties.description: The single most important value point to communicate
Additional value elements that reinforce the primary message
Resonant elements that create emotional connection
Whether the messaging uses customer language vs internal terminology

relationships.name: hasProofPoint
relationships.description: Evidence points that support value claims

relationships.name: customizedFor
relationships.description: Stakeholder segments the messaging is customized for

@graph.name: Proof Point
@graph.description: A specific piece of evidence or validation that supports value proposition claims. Proof points make the value proposition credible and tangible.

@graph.name: Value Evidence
@graph.description: Documented proof that the solution delivers promised value. Includes case studies, testimonials, ROI calculations, performance metrics, and comparative analyses.

properties.description: Description of the evidence and what it demonstrates
Quantified outcome demonstrated by the evidence

@graph.name: Implementation Path
@graph.description: The process and approach for customers to adopt and realize value from the solution. Includes onboarding, time to value, and success metrics.

properties.description: Expected time until customers realize value

relationships.name: hasStep
relationships.description: Sequential steps in the implementation process

relationships.name: measuredBy
relationships.description: Metrics used to measure implementation success

@graph.name: Success Metric
@graph.description: A measurable indicator used to track value realization and solution performance. Success metrics should align with customer objectives and value proposition claims.

properties.description: Description of what the metric measures
How the metric is measured and tracked

@graph.name: Customer Journey
@graph.description: The end-to-end experience and sequence of interactions a customer has when encountering the problem, discovering the solution, and realizing value.

relationships.name: hasStage
relationships.description: Stages within the customer journey

relationships.name: hasTouchpoint
relationships.description: Touchpoints where customer interacts with solution or problem

@graph.name: Value Proposition Canvas
@graph.description: A strategic tool that maps the complete value proposition by aligning customer jobs, pains, and gains with products/services, pain relievers, and gain creators.

relationships.name: documentsCustomerProfile
relationships.description: The customer profile side of the canvas

relationships.name: documentsValueMap
relationships.description: The value map side of the canvas

changeHistory.description: Created comprehensive Value Proposition Development Framework Ontology based on industry best practices and structured methodologies
